prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 3mm line survey setup1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Setup No.1 for 3mm line survey toward NGC 7469. LSB:89.35-93.15GHz USB:101.48-105.25GHz

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
============ NOTICE ============ We will combine this observation with our accepted ALMA cycle 1 program toward the same region (Izumi et al. 2012.1.00165.S) to fully cover 3mm range (86-116GHz). Therefore, we request the same sensitivity, angular/velocity resolution as the cycle 1 program. We show induvidual number relates to the technical justification in the following. ================================
- Requested Sensitivity:
We request the sensitivity of 0.45 mJy in 0".65 beam at the velocity resolution of 20 km/s (same as the cycle 1 program). In this setup (named as "Setup No.1"), HNC(1-0) and HC3N(10-9) will be observed, for example. With this sensitivity, some lines which have similar flux density as HCN(1-0) (~15 mJy; we set this value in the "Peak Line Flux Density per Beam" pane of the "Expected Source Properties" section) can be detected at ~30 sigma significance. The largest structure we assume is at most 5", which can be entirely covered by the maximum angular scale of band 3 at this angular resolution. Since the molecular line width is ~ 500 km/s (FWZI) in the nuclear region of NGC 7469, the proposed velocity resolution (20 km/s) is enough to spectrally resolve the emission.
- Imaging requirements:
The requested beam size is set to 0.65" (or 200 pc at the distance of NGC 7469). Having a similar uv-coverage throughout the observation is also important for taking line ratios.
- Correlator setup:
In this setup, we will use four basebands, which consist of one spectral window of 1.875 GHz width for each, respectively. Therefore, frequency range of 89.35-93.15 GHz (LSB) and 101.48-105.25 GHz (USB) will be covered in this setup. The channels will be smoothed to a requested velocity width of 20 km/s considering the large velocity width (FWZI ~ 500 km/s) of molecular line emissions in the nuclear region of NGC 7469.
- Calibration:
Default calibration is enough.
- Bandpass accuracy:
Default calibration is enough.
- Scheduling/time constraints:
Please schedule dynamically.
- Data rate:
OT says the rate is 5.4 MB/s, which is comfortably below the limit. Note that since this is a line survey program, we need all of the observed data, even if no line is detected (non-detection is also meaningful). Therefore, please do not cut off any of the data.
- Special constraints on standard observing modes:
We do not request such constraints.

The channels will be smoothed to a requested velocity width of 20 km/s considering the large velocity width (FWZI ~ 500 km/s) of molecular line emissions in the nuclear region of NGC 7469.

In this setup, we will use four basebands, which consist of one spectral window of 1.875 GHz width for each, respectively. The channels will be smoothed to a requested velocity width of 20 km/s considering the large velocity width (FWZI ~ 500 km/s) of molecular line emissions in the nuclear region of NGC 7469.

- Data rate:
OT says the rate is 5.4 MB/s, which is comfortably below the limit. Note that since this is a line survey program, we need all of the observed data, even if no line is detected (non-detection is also meaningful). Therefore, please do not cut off any of the data.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 3mm line survey setup4
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Setup No.4 for 3mm line survey toward NGC 7469. One side band is used. USB:112.5-116.15GHz

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
============ NOTICE ============ We will combine this observation with our accepted ALMA cycle 1 program toward the same region (Izumi et al. 2012.1.00165.S) to fully cover 3mm range (86-116GHz). Therefore, we request the same sensitivity, angular/velocity resolution as the cycle 1 program. We show induvidual number relates to the technical justification in the following. ================================
- Requested Sensitivity:
We request the sensitivity of 0.45 mJy in 0".65 beam at the velocity resolution of 20 km/s (same as the cycle 1 program). In this setup (named as "Setup No.4"), 12CN(1-0) and 12CO(1-0) will be observed, for example. With this sensitivity, some lines which have similar flux density as HCN(1-0) (~15 mJy; we set this value in the "Peak Line Flux Density per Beam" pane of the "Expected Source Properties" section) can be detected at ~30 sigma significance. The largest structure we assume is at most 5", which can be entirely covered by the maximum angular scale of band 3 at this angular resolution. Since the molecular line width is ~ 500 km/s (FWZI) in the nuclear region of NGC 7469, the proposed velocity resolution (20 km/s) is enough to spectrally resolve the emission.
- Imaging requirements:
The requested beam size is set to 0.65" (or 200 pc at the distance of NGC 7469). Having a similar uv-coverage throughout the observation is also important for taking line ratios.
- Correlator setup:
In this setup, we will use two basebands in LSB only, which consist of one spectral window of 1.875 GHz width for each, respectively. Therefore, frequency range of 112.50-116.15 GHz (LSB) will be covered in this setup. The channels will be smoothed to a requested velocity width of 20 km/s considering the large velocity width (FWZI ~ 500 km/s) of molecular line emissions in the nuclear region of NGC 7469.
- Calibration:
Default calibration is enough.
- Bandpass accuracy:
Default calibration is enough.
- Scheduling/time constraints:
Please schedule dynamically.
- Data rate:
OT says the rate is 2.7 MB/s, which is comfortably below the limit. Note that since this is a line survey program, we need all of the observed data, even if no line is detected (non-detection is also meaningful). Therefore, please do not cut off any of the data.
- Special constraints on standard observing modes:
We do not request such constraints.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We propose to conduct a line survey toward the central kpc region of the nearby type-1 Seyfert galaxy, NGC 7469, at 3 mm wavelength. This observation will be combined with our accepted cycle 1 program toward the same region, to fully cover 86-116 GHz range.
From this observation, we will investigate the effect of AGN and starburst activity on the molecular materials. For example, we focus on the abundance variation of (1) HCN and CN, which are expected to be enhanced in AGNs, (2) molecules sensitive to UV radiation such as HNCO, which can be used to probe the phase of starburst activity, and (3) dust-related molecules such as SO, CH3OH, SiO, CH3CN, to investigate their properties especially in AGNs.
All observed properties will be compared with chemical models and results of our ALMA cycle 0/1 programs toward NGC 1097, 253, and 1068, to further investigate the effect of AGN and starburst on molecular properties. In addition, NGC 7469 hosts a bright type-1 AGN whose Eddington ratio is comparable to QSOs. Therefore, this observation can also serve as a local template of molecular properties for exploring high-redshift QSOs in future ALMA cycles.
